Change has been successfully merged

Hello; The comments on [fw_update: Add encode req & decode resp for query_downtream_identifiers](https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/libpldm/+/70729) also apply to this patch. Please identify the corresponding issues and fix.
Hi, I've modified the code based on the suggestions from the two previous changes, please review, thanks.
Done

Hello. The blocking concern on this patch is that it's trusting untrustworthy input. That must be fixed before we can reconsider submitting it.

I've made a few other minor comments as well.
Add the whitespace in the relevant patch instead. It shouldn't be part of this patch.
Done
As above.
Done
We shouldn't be renaming this? Where did it get introduced?

We indeed shouldn't, clange-tidy told me to do that instead. I tried to keep this macro unchanged, but the error showed up:
```
@@ -66,7 +66,7 @@ struct variable_field;
 /** @brief Minimum length of device descriptor, 2 bytes for descriptor type,
  *         2 bytes for descriptor length and atleast 1 byte of descriptor data
  */
-#define PLDM_FWUP_DEVICE_DESCRIPTOR_MIN_LEN    5
+#define PLDM_FWUP_DEVICE_DESCRIPTOR_MIN_LEN 5
```

This macro is used to some stable APIs such as `decode_firmware_device_id_record`.
Done
Requests don't have a completion code?
Done
completion?
Done
This is out-only, so should be `@param[out]`
Done
As above.
Done

I can't accept this sorry, it's not safe at all. Much better would be to replace all of this with:

```
return pldm_msgbuf_span_remaining(buf,
    (void **)&downstream_device_param_table->ptr,
    &downstream_device_param_table->length);
```

Someone can then feed the content of `downstream_device_param_table` into another `pldm_msgbuf` (via another public API) for subsequent decoding.

Again, the translation between a `struct pldm_msgbuf` and `struct variable_field` is something we can make a bit more ergonomic if necessary.

I don't think that works, because while Table 20 says to refer to Table 14, it's actually table 21 that's relevant. Table 21 has an extra parameter at the front (`DownstreamDeviceIndex`), and so you need a decoding function specific to the `GetDOwnstreamFirmwareParameters` response. However, aside from decoding that (extra) first field, I think you can then call `decode_get_firmware_parameters_resp_comp_entry()` in the implementation. Please confirm my understanding for yourself and respond in this thread.

Hi, I summarized the difference between Table 21 & 14, they are different at the first three data members, since Table 21 is not append just 1 `DownstreamDeviceIndex` but don't have 2 data defined in Table 14, for concern of cohesion, I personally prefer to implement another decode function for Table 21, I've written to code and their test cases, please review, thanks.

| Type| Table 21 data | Type | Table 14 data |   |
|--------|--------------------------------|--------|--------------------------------|---|
| uint16 | DownstreamDeviceIndex          | uint16 | ComponentClassification        |   |
| N/A    | N/A                            | uint16 | ComponentIdentifier            |   |
| N/A    | N/A                            | uint8  | ComponentClassificationIndex   |   |
| uint32 | ActiveComponentComparisonStamp | uint32 | ActiveComponentComparisonStamp |   |
| ...    | ...same                         | ...    | ...same                        |   |
Good catch! SGTM.
Hello, the main concern is around the differences between Table 14 and Table 21. I have some other comments inline.
Please note the table number(s). For instance, this is a combination of tables 19 and 20, and that needs some explanation.
Done
Hello, I have some comments inline, but I'm more confident in the implementation this time. Thanks for reworking it.

Can we please specify this as `char active_comp_release_date[9]` so it can be used as a `NUL`-terminated string? The encode function can drop the final `NUL` when constructing the wire-format message, and the decoder can ensure the final byte is `NUL` when populating the struct member.

Also consider defining a macro for the magic number.
Done
As above: `char pending_comp_release_date[9];` (taking into account the decision on a macro definition for the magic number).
Done

Can you please separate the description with a `-`? It makes it easier to find where the description starts.

Please audit the rest of the doxygen documentation you've added for this.
Done

Okay, so in between your last patchset and this one, I added a checklist for making changes to libpldm. I'm hoping the checklist helps us achieve consistency in API design (among other things).

Part of the checklist requests that new functions return negative `errno` values:

https://github.com/openbmc/libpldm/blob/main/docs/checklists/changes.md?plain=1#L108-L112

Can you please update the documentation and the implementation to conform with that?

Please also audit the rest of the functions you've added so they adhere with this.
Sure, thanks for reminding, I've changed the `@return` into `errno` and list all possible return values, and check each items on the checklist myself, please review.
Done
There's some unnecessary whitespace here. Can you please trim that off and audit the rest of the change for any further instances?
Done
We can pass in the `struct variable_field *` that we extracted the region into via `decode_get_downstream_firmware_params_resp()` here, right? That would feel more ergonomic to me.
True, thanks for the suggestion, done.

See comment in the header about return values. This should be `-EINVAL`.

Please audit the rest of the patch for this.

Done.

I modifed the code based on the commit you contributed before: https://github.com/openbmc/libpldm/commit/f490a38f7c78dee6d71db0706d8ddbb5d37c95c1, please let me know if I miss anythiing else.
... and switch to `pldm_msgbuf_init_errno(...)`.
Done
Don't need this one, as it will be handled by `pldm_msgbuf_init_cc()` below.
Done
And this becomes `return 0`.
Done
Maybe we can add a helper to extract a string for this.

Yes, I think that will be more elegant, I'll have to do some calculation for the real data length in my code for now, like this:
```
pldm_msgbuf_extract_array_uint8(
		buf, entry->active_comp_release_date,
		PLDM_FWUP_COMPONENT_RELEASE_DATA_LEN -
			1 /*minus the null terminator*/);
```

But I think this should be a seperate commit for refactoring purpose?

Well, I'm concerned about the types. Whether `char` is signed or unsigned is platform-dependent, but `uint8_t` is always unsigned.

Are you happy to add an implementation of `pldm_msgbuf_extract_array_char()`?
Done, add `pldm_msgbuf_extract_array_char()` and related test cases, please let me know if there is any concern.
Done
This should be `pldm_msgbuf_destroy_consumed()`?
Done

All the test functions you've added should be individually guarded to ensure the tests don't fail to link when the library is built with `-Dabi=deprecated,stable`:

```
Found ninja-1.11.1.git.kitware.jobserver-1 at /home/andrew/.local/bin/ninja
Cleaning... 12 files.
[58/62] Linking target tests/dsp_firmware_update
FAILED: tests/dsp_firmware_update 
c++  -o tests/dsp_firmware_update tests/dsp_firmware_update.p/dsp_firmware_update.cpp.o -Wl,--as-needed -Wl,--no-undefined '-Wl,-rpath,$ORIGIN/../src' -Wl,-rpath-link,/home/andrew/src/openbmc.org/openbmc/libpldm/origin/tmp.cvHWAXriQc/src -Wl,--start-group src/libpldm.so.0.8.0 subprojects/googletest/libgtest.a subprojects/googletest/libgtest_main.a subprojects/googletest/libgmock.a -Wl,--end-group -pthread
/usr/bin/ld: tests/dsp_firmware_update.p/dsp_firmware_update.cpp.o: in function `GetDownstreamFirmwareParameters_goodPathEncodeRequest_Test::TestBody()':
/home/andrew/src/openbmc.org/openbmc/libpldm/origin/tmp.cvHWAXriQc/../tests/dsp/firmware_update.cpp:1697:(.text+0x105b4): undefined reference to `encode_get_downstream_firmware_params_req'
/usr/bin/ld: tests/dsp_firmware_update.p/dsp_firmware_update.cpp.o: in function `GetDownstreamFirmwareParameters_encodeRequestInvalidTransferOperationFlag_Test::TestBody()':
/home/andrew/src/openbmc.org/openbmc/libpldm/origin/tmp.cvHWAXriQc/../tests/dsp/firmware_update.cpp:1719:(.text+0x10808): undefined reference to `encode_get_downstream_firmware_params_req'
/usr/bin/ld: tests/dsp_firmware_update.p/dsp_firmware_update.cpp.o: in function `GetDownstreamFirmwareParameters_encodeRequestErrorBufSize_Test::TestBody()':
/home/andrew/src/openbmc.org/openbmc/libpldm/origin/tmp.cvHWAXriQc/../tests/dsp/firmware_update.cpp:1739:(.text+0x1095e): undefined reference to `encode_get_downstream_firmware_params_req'
/usr/bin/ld: tests/dsp_firmware_update.p/dsp_firmware_update.cpp.o: in function `GetDownstreamFirmwareParameters_goodPathDecodeResponse_Test::TestBody()':
/home/andrew/src/openbmc.org/openbmc/libpldm/origin/tmp.cvHWAXriQc/../tests/dsp/firmware_update.cpp:1797:(.text+0x13059): undefined reference to `decode_get_downstream_firmware_params_resp'
/usr/bin/ld: tests/dsp_firmware_update.p/dsp_firmware_update.cpp.o: in function `GetDownstreamFirmwareParameters_decodeResponseInvalidLength_Test::TestBody()':
/home/andrew/src/openbmc.org/openbmc/libpldm/origin/tmp.cvHWAXriQc/../tests/dsp/firmware_update.cpp:1865:(.text+0x15ed2): undefined reference to `decode_get_downstream_firmware_params_resp'
/usr/bin/ld: /home/andrew/src/openbmc.org/openbmc/libpldm/origin/tmp.cvHWAXriQc/../tests/dsp/firmware_update.cpp:1889:(.text+0x16177): undefined reference to `decode_downstream_device_parameter_table_entry'
/usr/bin/ld: tests/dsp_firmware_update.p/dsp_firmware_update.cpp.o: in function `GetDownstreamFirmwareParameters_goodPathDecodeDownstreamDeivceParamTable_Test::TestBody()':
/home/andrew/src/openbmc.org/openbmc/libpldm/origin/tmp.cvHWAXriQc/../tests/dsp/firmware_update.cpp:1954:(.text+0x1be55): undefined reference to `decode_downstream_device_parameter_table_entry'
collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status
[62/62] Linking target tests/oem_ibm_fileio
ninja: build stopped: subcommand failed.
```

This issue is caught by running `./scripts/pre-submit`.

For an example of how to resolve this issue, see the way this change guards each test:

https://github.com/openbmc/libpldm/commit/a6fa5559a934a887f436a1011de8ba5554221b60#diff-e0782f432277f708536334f4fbbae580d428042a8f6c18819078de9e22d5c1fe

This approach allows us to stabilise each API individually.
Done

You need to make this conditional on `NDEBUG` being defined. If you run `./scripts/pre-submit` this assertion will fail when the build is configured with `--buildtype=release`:

```
[ RUN      ] GetDownstreamFirmwareParameters.decodeResponseInvalidLength
../tests/dsp/firmware_update.cpp:1883: Failure
Death test: decode_downstream_device_parameter_table_entry( currentDevice, paramTableLen, &entry, &activeCompVerStr, &pendingCompVerStr)
    Result: failed to die.
 Error msg:
[  DEATH   ]

[  FAILED  ] GetDownstreamFirmwareParameters.decodeResponseInvalidLength (0 ms)
```
See how this change solves the problem:

https://github.com/openbmc/libpldm/commit/fbaea23332f750c7c67d6fec6144df2fc3f90f2a
Done, thanks for the hint, I've run the script locally and all tests passed.
We can probably add helpers for string insertion as well.
I think this should be a seperate commit for refactoring purpose?
No, the types need to be correct in this patch, as it affects the public API of the library.
Done, added helper `pldm_msgbuf_insert_array_char`, added related test cases to reach 100% line coverage (verified by local-ci-build).

Hello, thanks for addressing the review comments. I have a few more inline. The critical thing is that we get the bits that are in `include/libpldm/firmware_update.h` right. Changing the library's public API after the fact is a difficult process, so if we catch things in review that can be improved, it's best they're dealt with before we merge the work.
Please move this to `### Added` under the `## [Unreleased]` section.
Done
Thinking about this some more perhaps we should align this more tightly to the spec. I think we should define it to be `8`, not `9`, and then we do the arithmetic in the struct declaration below.
Done

Make this

```
uint8_t active_comp_release_data[PLDM_FWUP_COMPONENT_RELEASE_DATA_LEN + 1];
```

I noticed that I cannot use `pack_pldm_header_errno()` since there is no declaration for it in `include/libpldm/base.h`, I saw it is marked as a `Internal functions` in `src/dsp/base.h`, but `pack_pldm_header()` still return a CC, is it expected?

You should `#include "dsp/base.h"` and use `pack_pldm_header_errno()`.

`include/libpldm/base.h` is part of the library's _public_ API - it must only expose API details relevant to the _users_ of libpldm (as opposed to the _implementation_ of libpldm, which is what you're changing here). I'm not yet ready to expose `pack_pldm_header_errno()` to library users, thus it's declared in the internal header.
Done

Hello! Nice work; I have some pretty minor comments remaining. Thanks for iterating on the patch!

I understand what you mean, but I think what you've written could be confusing to some. Can we rewrite this as:

> The "Length of ComponentVersionString" field is 1 byte, so "ComponentVersionString" can be at most 255 characters. Allocate memory for it and append 1 byte for null termination ...
Done
This needs to be `return pldm_msgbuf_span_remaining(buf, (void **)&data->ptr, &data->length);` so the subsequent iteration can decode the subsequent table entry.

I think this might not work since the `data`'s ptr is const, and the `variable_field data` has been initilized by `decode_get_downstream_firmware_params_resp()`, use `pldm_msgbuf_span_remaining()` would return `-EINVAL` caused by the data verification in the function:
```
pldm_msgbuf_span_remaining(struct pldm_msgbuf *ctx, void **cursor, size_t *len)
{
	assert(ctx);

	if (!ctx->cursor || !cursor || *cursor || !len) { << trigger `*cursor`
		return pldm_msgbuf_status(ctx, EINVAL);
	}
	...
}
```

This leads to two seperate problem:
1. `ptr` in `variable_field` is a const pointer.
  - `ptr` cannot be assigned to a new address.
2. `pldm_msgbuf_span_remaining()` assumes the `cursor` should point to `NULL`.
  - `variable_field data` has been initilized.
  
Do you have any thought about this? And please let me know if I was wrong.

> Yes, but we're defining that - we can change it so it isn't const?

Changing the `ptr` into a non-const pointer causes many errors and warnings, including the stable APIs, such as
```
../src/dsp/firmware_update.c:374:34: error: assignment discards ‘const’ qualifier from pointer target type [-Werror=discarded-qualifiers]
  374 |         package_version_str->ptr =

or

../tests/dsp/firmware_update.cpp:2020:16: error: invalid conversion from ‘const uint8_t*’ {aka ‘const unsigned char*’} to ‘uint8_t*’ {aka ‘unsigned char*’} [-fpermissive]
 2020 |         .ptr = reinterpret_cast<const uint8_t*>(versionsStr),

```

Also, assigning the `ptr` to `NULL` is not acceptable too.
```
../src/dsp/firmware_update.c: In function ‘decode_downstream_device_parameter_table_entry’:
../src/dsp/firmware_update.c:1184:19: error: assignment of member ‘ptr’ in read-only object
 1184 |         data->ptr = NULL;
```

It looks like this change would cause many side effects, I personally recommand that let the users to calculate the offset on themself by the macro `PLDM_DOWNSTREAM_DEVICE_PARAMETER_ENTRY_MIN_LEN`, `active_comp_ver_str_len`, and `pending_comp_ver_str_len` in this change.

Unfortunately your reply above isn't making a lot of sense to me.

> Changing the ptr into a non-const pointer causes many errors and warnings, including the stable APIs

This function is literally annotated with `LIBPLDM_ABI_TESTING`. Changes to it are not going to affect stable APIs - given that it's not yet even merged into the code-base, it can't even affect the _implementation_ of stable APIs (let alone break them). It's not clear to me what changes you made to get the effect you've reported in the output above.

> I personally recommand that let the users to calculate the offset on themself by the macro PLDM_DOWNSTREAM_DEVICE_PARAMETER_ENTRY_MIN_LEN, active_comp_ver_str_len, and pending_comp_ver_str_len in this change

Sorry, but most definitely no. That kind of API design falls into the [What If I Don't Actually Like My Users?](https://ozlabs.org/~rusty/index.cgi/tech/2008-04-01.html) category as far as I'm concerned, it's just far too easy for it to go wrong and cause CVEs.

libpldm exists to provide ergonomic and (as much as we can) safe decoding of PLDM messages. Let's please try to keep that true for our users.
I've made the change and the tests as you had written them pass with a minor change to drop the `const` on the relevant `struct variable_field` variable.

Ah, yes, that would cause a lot of grief 😊 The code I ended up with to avoid that problem is a little verbose, but we can refactor it later to improve the ergonomics if more cases appear. Thanks for your patience here. Designing these APIs can be tricky 😊
Thank you for your example, it helped me understand quickly!

While "Tested" sections are encouraged at a project level I don't require them for repositories I maintain. Hello, I've made a few responses and suggestions inline.

The documentation for `active` and `pending` must note that the objects pointed-to must be at least as large as `entry->active_comp_ver_str_len + 1` and `entry->pending_comp_ver_str_len + 1` respectively.
Done

This should be `pldm_msgbuf_destroy()`, rather than `pldm_msgbuf_destroy_consumed()`. The caller might over-allocate the buffer, and we don't want to return an error in that case. We should also indicate the size of the buffer consumed back to the caller. Perhaps `payload_length` could be an `in,out` parameter (would need to change to `size_t *`)? We could also return the size, but I'm wondering whether we want that as a general pattern. We can't use `ssize_t` for the return type easily as it only supports `-1` as a negative value.

I have a few questions about it:
1. Do you mean that the `payload_length` should minus the part that the decode function has proccessed, so that the caller can know how many buffers are still remain?
2. What kind of condition would cause the `payload_length` be a negative value? In my perspective, it should always be a positive value, pop out an `errno` if there is any failure during the decode function.
Done
also needs to check `versions->ptr` and `versions->length`.

I've investigated this and the lint seems to falsely trigger on any double underscore. C's reserved identifiers (approximately) match `^_[A-Z].+` and `^__.+`. `pldm__msgbuf_extract_array_void` does not match either of those as it has the `pldm` prefix prior to the double-underscore.
Does this zero-initialise the array? Can we make that more explicit? Please address this concern on the other test cases below.
